RMP Executive Summary Insert Update Submittal (1-30-06)

?Rhodia, Spartanburg Facility:

Rhodia, SA, is a world wide company.  The Spartanburg Facility is part of the Novecare Enterprise within the Rhodia, SA?s North American sector, Rhodia Inc.  The Spartanburg Facility has been operating safely for 28 years, producing products sold to consumer product manufacturers around the world.  Many products produced in the Spartanburg facility are use in personal care products such as soaps, body washes, shampoos, pharmaceuticals, baby wipes, and numerous other useful and hygienic products.  A group of products serve industrial type markets including latex manufacture and agricultural chemicals. The Rhodia facility has 61 dedicated and safety conscious employees.   The employees are skilled at the manufacture of about 350 formulations using near 125 raw materials.

The facility uses state-of-the-art technologies to manufacture, monitor, examine and control the processes.  Some of these are, Triconnex tridundant safety control systems, Allen Bradley redundant PLC controllers, OS-PI Data gathering and analysis Software, In-house Layer-Of-Protection Analysis software for risk review, a dedicated and well trained operations, maintenance and technical staff.

Rhodia, Spartanburg Facility, operates a safe and environmentally conscious facility and has done so for 28 years.  Rhodia, Spartanburg Facility?s, commitment to health, safety and the environment is captured in the plant HS&E Policy:

Our employees represent a cross-section of our community committed to the manufacture of high quality chemical products.  The care each of us shows for the welfare of the plant, our neighbors, our fellow employees, and the environment, is a core value.  We are committed to the continual recognition of workplace hazards and proactive reduction or elimination of risk.

Finally, we in Spartanburg firmly believe that ALL accidents and environmental incidents are preventable ALL of the time.

Thes

e commitments are the basis by which we conduct all our day to day activities.

Rhodia, Spartanburg Facility, uses many risk management tools to discover, analyze, understand, reduce and eliminate understand possible risks to the neighborhood and the facility.  The technical, operations, and maintenance staff, working together, are trained to use these tools and devices, making every effort possible to minimize community impact.  Rhodia Spartanburg is continually updating and improving the information and standards at the site in an effort to strive for Health Safety and Environmental excellence.

While not the last PHA study done at the site, in 2003 a 5 year revalidation of the Alkoxylation Process was conducted..  Many hazards were resolved in 2004 and 2005.

The Spartanburg Facility is ISO-9001-2000 certified, and has won numerous awards for safety and environmental performance.  In 2004, Rhodia, Spartanburg Facility, received a multi-year based award from Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District for Superior Environmental Compliance.  Rhodia?s Spartanburg Facility, continually works to improve safety, environmental concerns, and community awareness.  In 2003 and 2005 The Spartanburg facility held a Plant Open House to help improve awareness within our community. The Spartanburg facility conducted industrial hygiene tests and a regime of perimeter monitoring, all indicating no actionable levels of regulated chemicals.  In 2005 Rhodia Spartanburg received the 2004 SOCMA  Achievement award for exceptional management systems.

The Spartanburg Facility remains an active and progressive team of dedicated employees working every hour of the day to maintain high standards of safe operations and environmentally sound activities.

Rhodia Inc.,

?Regulated Substances Handled: 

Ethylene oxide, propylene oxide and allyl alcohol.

?Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies: 

The facility acc

idental release prevention policy can be generally summarized as follows.   All facility personnel will be trained in and expected to comply with the site-specific policies pertaining to accidental release prevention.  Primary accidental release prevention policy documents are found in:
                         >Engineering & Maintenance procedures
                         >Environmental (WWTP) operating procedures
                         >Production operating procedures
                         >Site-wide risk management procedures

?Emergency response policies: 

The facility emergency response policy generally can be summarized as follows.  Site facility personnel training requires personnel to comply with the site-specific policies pertaining to emergency response.  Primary emergency response policy documents are found in:     
                         >Risk Management Procedures (RM007 Emergency Response)
                         >Engineering & Maintenance procedures
                         >Environmental (WWTP) operating procedures
                         >Production operating procedures
                         >Site-wide risk management procedures

                  
?General Accidental Release Prevention Program: 

The site?s Risk Management Procedure RM007, Emergency Response, addresses response to any incident within the site utilizing an Incident Command form of management control and response. Administrative controls to limit potential off-site impact include chain of command management with specific overlapping staff assignments for release prevention, emergency response, etc.; twenty four hour a day, seven days per week facility staffing; active fire watch during holiday shut down periods; active membership in and coordination with the Spartanburg Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) (Spartanburg County Emergency Preparedness Department), and active coordination with the Arkwright, Croft and Roebuck Voluntary Fire Departments.  Mitigation meas

ures to limit potential off-site impact include state of the art leak detection and control systems; railcar unloading station equipped with a three car emergency deluge system; dedicated diesel powered emergency fire water supply system; emergency alarms throughout the facility.
 
?Chemical Specific Prevention Steps: 

These issues are already addressed above with respect to accidental release prevention policies, and emergency response policies.  

?Five Year Accident History:

Between 1996-and present there have been no releases from Spartanburg?s RMP-covered processes involving a regulated substance and which caused any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; nor any known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. 

?Emergency Response Program: 

This program is a defined command and control structure that emphasizes the safety of the employee, community, environment and finally the company assets.  This issue is already addressed above under the Emergency Response Policy topic.
  
?Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  

Among other things, periodic review and implementation, as appropriate, of plant process safety plan, and resolution of periodic process hazard analysis recommendations.   
   
Prepared 1-30-06 by Brian N. Glenn, Operations Manager
